Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2010 08:35AM precioustime wrote: I had my husband take a pic on my camera phone while getting prepared for BMX.  I have not had reconstruction or planning on it in the future.  For me-- it is good and bad memories--I'm able to look at what I once had--BUT when I do look at them-- I think of them as being diseased and what I had gone through.  Loretta
Posts.Title: Nude/Topless Photo Shoot Anne068 Oddball1

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2010 08:50AM precioustime wrote: I am 4 months post BMX and will have to be honest and say that there are times that I miss my breasts -- especially when I am walking in the Mall past a Victoria's Secret store or really like a blouse and realize-- oh, that is not going to work with my flatness!   On the other hand-- losing my breasts were a small price to pay for living and I do not want to have to go through any unnecessary surgeries for others. I could not believe at the Dr.'s office the other day- a girl commented to me after she found out I had a BMX that she would like to lose her large breasts!  I responded "oh no you don't!"    She probably said that trying to make me feel better?  Not!  Probably the most challenging part of not having breasts for me is when I give my husband or son a hug I tend to not let them get close to my chest area because of the sensitivity feeling I have there-- or maybe it's a protection thing?  The other day for kicks, I put on a sports bra and stuffed it and tried giving them a hug that way-- and it worked!  Hopefully in time after more of the feeling in my chest comes back-- I will not have this issue:)  Until then-- I am most Thankful to be here today with or without breasts! Loretta
Posts.Title: I'd rather be flat than fake...I think. Suzybelle robinlbe

Posts.Content: May 1, 2010 06:27AM precioustime wrote: Ruthbru- Yes, that was one of the first things I learned after surgery.  Thanks.

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2010 07:08PM precioustime wrote: Ruth-  I totally agree with you that as time goes on I will be less freaked out about this whole lymphadema issue!  Just something else to learn and deal with, right:)  The funny thing about it is I had "No Idea" there was such a thing as Lymphedema before I had my BMX and axillary surgery.  It's only after the fact that we learn of possible S/E's. Thanks again ladies.  You are ALL AWESOME and STRONG WOMEN!! Loretta
Posts.Title: 3 cuts on my Lymphadema hand within 2 days! precioustime ruthbru

Posts.Content: Jun 21, 2010 07:16AM precioustime wrote: Jenn-  Congrats on your 1 year Victory over Cancer!!  I was also diagnosed last year--6/9/09 and am claiming victory over cancer!!  I will go in on June 29, 2010 for PET scan and CT scan follow up -- HOWEVER, I am still claiming victory over cancer!!  I feel Awesome other than pneumonitis caused from radiation -- BUT out of everything that we have been through-- that is nothing, right!! Congrats again and together we will walk in victory and only look back to see the mountain that we have climbed to help others that are making the same journey now that we have Survived:) Loretta
Posts.Title: ONE YEAR AGO TODAY...... jenn3 jenn3

Posts.Content: Jul 2, 2010 08:25AM precioustime wrote: I had 33 Rad treatments including the mediastinal area.  2 weeks into treatments I had developed a dry cough and was told it couldn't be from Rads so soon.  It is now 3 1/2 months post Rads and have had a recent PET/CT scan-- the good news is that there is no evidence of tumor-- the other news is that there was mild pleural inflammatory changes likely secondary to radiation therapy. Not sure if pleurisy is the same? I have not had any sharp pains as some of you have described -- only really notice when I wake up in the morning -- cough with mucous and then if I have a good laugh-- I cough. I had a 6 month follow up with the surgeon yesterday and he said "pneumonitis" -- is probably what I have and that there is really nothing you can do about it -- that it's probably at it's worse right now -- 3 months post Rads.  Since Rads -- I was put on a 4 week regimen of steroids which worked amazingly -- a few weeks after steroids -- I noticed a cough with a lot of mucous and was then put on Albuterol inhaler which seems to help a little.
Posts.Title: Radiation-Induced Pleurisy? annac sdianel

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2010 03:31PM precioustime wrote: We are all different I know-- what works for me is that when the thoughts of cancer start to enter my mind-- I right then start thinking positive thoughts-- like I'm alive-- I feel good for everything that I've been through-- I'm blessed to have a beautiful family and am not going to allow negative thoughts room to grow!  When I am reminded physically when I take a shower every night-- I look in the mirror and place my hands over my scars and thank God for making it thus far !!  As time goes by -- and treatments end -- I believe that we will have many days of getting to a place of peace.  In some strange way-- I am actually at more peace in my life now then before my diagnosis. It's amazing how something tragic can turn out for my good. God is Good!! Loretta
Posts.Title: A Whole Day Without (Not much at least) Thinking About Cancer pupfoster1 precioustime

Posts.Content: May 16, 2010 03:37PM precioustime wrote: Suepen:  I had 33 RAD treatments.  It is all accumulative-- meaning that I didn't really have any skin reactions the first couple of weeks but near the end and especially "after" treatments had ended is where I experienced the worse skin side effects.  For me- it took about 3 weeks after Radiation to where my skin started to heal-- for others it might not have taken so long?  I had a bollus placed on me for all 33 treatments in which I was told by the Oncologist that they were treating me like if I had skin cancer and wanted the skin to react. I was given a prescription for Silvadene after about 3 weeks of having RADS in which I used ALOT of until I started seeing skin improvements. Take Care-- This will soon be behind you. Loretta
Posts.Title: Skin Breakdown - how long to heal? suzieq60 grdnslve

Posts.Content: Dec 4, 2009 11:18AM precioustime wrote: Kendra-- You made it!  It's December 4th and by this time your surgery is probably over with and you are on your way to recovery I will also be having a Bilateral Mastectomy with rt. axillary nodes removed on December 14th and am curious to know how things went with your surgery.  I hear the drains are the worst part?  Does anyone have suggestions on what I would need to take with me to the hospital? On the positive side of surgery-- I am sooooo ready to get this port removed!  I believe that's what made up my mind to not get reconstruction at this point because just having this port in has really bothered me for 5 months while I was having Chemo.      One Day At A Time, Right    Loretta

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2010 10:12AM precioustime wrote: Thank-You Ladies, Chasinghope-- I wish you the best going through Chemo.  I am almost 3 months post Chemo and things are looking brighter!  Getting my energy back and feeling more like myself!  Time for RADS in February-- alot of women say that RADS is easier than Chemo so this is encouraging  I use to love using the eliptical machine--one of my favorites, so maybe I'll start out with that and using lite weights on my left arm and see what happens.
Posts.Title: 5 weeks post BMX-- What is over doing it? precioustime precioustime

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2011 07:04AM precioustime wrote: KerryMac-- I absolutely Love your hair!!  I was just sitting here thinking about getting mine cut very very short because of all the curls -- BUT looking at yours is giving me hope that it just might look good after it grows out a bit:)  I haven't been on here that much lately because believe it or not-- there are times I "Forget" I even had breast cancer!!  This June will be 2 yrs. ago that I was diagnosed and it's been 1 yr. since treatments have ended!  Thank God!! I have recently changed my oncologist due to insurance change--so I am still scheduled for every 3 months!!  Sharon- If you haven't been taught how to do lymphatic massage -- it is very easy and helps A LOT!!  I was lucky enough to have gone to physical therapy shortly after surgery and started exercise as well as lymphatic massage in which I do almost every day!  My husband and I have recently opened a restaurant and I find myself pre-bussing tables and helping the servers out-- SO by the end of the night my arm is feeling tight, sometimes swollen even while wearing the sleeve.  I am so happy to be ALIVE that lymphedema and all the other opportunities that comes with our treatments are manageable and I WILL NOT GIVE UP!  Mind over Matter:) Much Love!  Loretta

Posts.Content: May 1, 2010 05:16PM precioustime wrote: OK- I did it!  I got my 3rd trim - and boy did I go SHORT!  3/8" in the back and sides and kept a little longer on top-- THE curls are gone though... he he I couldn't believe how much hair I really had -- it was way more than I thought!  I guess when you have curly hair it's hard to tell how long it is because it just wants to CURL:) My 4 year old son after we got home was asking his Dad why Jackie "the hair dresser" cut Mommy's hair like that!!!  I asked him if he liked it better the other way with the curls and he said "Yes"-- SO I guess we can't please everybody.....  Loretta

Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2010 11:02AM precioustime wrote: Nodapearl and Issymom: I am now 8 months post Chemo.  I also had hair growth on my face-- kind of like cotton candy post Chemo and read posts that women had shaved it off and it didn't come back.....  Well (LOL)  not in my case...  I find myself having to shave my face once a week!!!   However-- I would rather have to shave now then to have cotton candy on my face.....   As far as the hair on my head--- I have had 4 trims and wear my hair very short due to the fact that it came in very curly.  I think the Tamoxifen is also drying out my hair?  This time, I believe my hair is coming back with a  litte more of a wave then curls-- so maybe soon my hair will grow back the way it use to?  Until then-- so Thankful to have Hair!  Loretta

Posts.Content: May 1, 2010 09:44AM precioustime wrote: I am 6 months post Chemo and have had 2 trims so far.  My hair started growing out very straight and about 75% grey with the other mousey brown color.  I have colored my hair twice myself with Loreal product and my hair now is very very very curly and actually my DH calls me "FRO RETTA"   he he Last night I went to a Ladies Conference and was standing in line for book signing when another woman came up to me and said "Is your hair curly because of Chemo"....  Well at first, I was like oh Great!  BUT then she proceeded to tell me that she had Hodgkin's Lymphoma (I think I spelled that right)-- and that had been "15" years ago!!  I Love to hear these stories!! Anyway-- she said that most people probably wouldn't realize unless they had been through it and that my hair still looked cute..... Today I woke up thinking I might go and get another trim..... ummmm.... Loretta
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Apr 28, 2010 04:00PM precioustime wrote: Pure I have learned to enjoy each and every day of Life AND to do that-- I can not allow cancer to control any part of it!  Yes-- we have been diagnosed with cancer and gone through treatments and guess what-- We are still here!  Think about "what if" there was already a cure for Cancer....  o.k. now say that we are cured:)  There is still the possibility of not being around another day --- Everyone is going to Die and that is a fact.  Before our diagnosis did we sit around and think about death-- probably not -- SO why should we have to now?  My HOPE is that God is my Creator and that "everything" is in His control!  As long as I put my HOPE and TRUST in Him --I know that I am in good hands! Please be encouraged and know that you are not Alone  and when negative thoughts try to enter your mind -- REFUSE to accept them and LOOK at your surroundings and what you have RIGHT NOW as you LIVE! Loretta
Posts.Title: How Do you Find Hope Pure Bugs

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2010 10:45AM precioustime wrote: Paradiseflower- I'm not too sure about Bone Met symptoms -I'm sure someone will come along with experience and give their input.  I DO know that if you have dense breasts to please get an MRI!  I had yearly routine mammograms and not until I got an MRI 6/09 did they detect anything suspicious and come to find out I was later diagnosed at Stage IIIB breast cancer.  I started Chemo and after Chemo was complete they had me go for another mammogram that showed the largest tumor still there and all others gone.  Pathology report after surgery showed the largest tumor "gone"-- and (2) small tumors "still there"!!!!  I don't want to scare you-- it may be just the fact that you do have dense breast--BUT if it was me, I would get a second opinion if your doctor refuses you to get an MRI.  Wishing you the best! Loretta
Posts.Title: Bone Mets? I am so confused!!! paradiseflower Ezscriiibe

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2009 10:53AM precioustime wrote: Surgery on Monday went very well.  Visibly the Surgeon could not find any cancer!!  Just awaiting the pathology report--but am feeling quite positive.  Ladies--I have to tell you that I am so thankful I decided on having a bilateral mastectomy w/o reconstruction!  The surgeon came to my room yesterday morning and took off the bandages--at first I told him I might not look down-- however something inside said "it's ok" - and so I looked.  To my surprise, I wasn't freaked out!!  I am still "Me" and I no longer have to worry about mammograms, biopsies, etc!!!  I actually feel free and at peace WE CAN DO THIS!
Posts.Title: Neoadjudvant Chemo no surgery needed precioustime mumito

Posts.Content: Nov 20, 2009 06:00AM precioustime wrote: Thank you Ladies!  Maybe the reason the Oncologist was not sure if surgery or radiation was going to be needed -- was because they had biopsied 1 mediastinal lymph node (in chest) and it was positive.  Her thought was why take the breast if there is cancer in inoperable lymph node.  This was reason for neoadjudvant Chemo.  I believe she wants to see the results from PET scan and mammogram before going to Oncologist/Surgeon board to discuss my case?  I definitely agree with your comments on throwing everything at it!  At this point I am waiting to see the Oncologist 10/30/09 and hopefully will have a game plan by then.  The waiting is always the hardest part...

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2010 04:10PM precioustime wrote: Merilee-  I had neo adjudvant Chemo- BMX surgery and now am almost 1/2 way done with RADS.  After 6 treatments of TAC the PET scan showed no more signs of cancer except for a lymph node in the middle of my chest that shrank 1/4 of it's size.  HOWEVER after surgery, the Pathology report showed 2 tumors less than 1cm and 12 positive lymph nodes out of 18 in the axilla area!!!  I do not like going to RADS M-F and laying on a table for 20 minutes and getting skin reactions, HOWEVER - I don't like CANCER even more and do not want to regret in the future that I could of and should of and I am throwing EVERYTHING I CAN at this beast to GO AWAY AND STAY AWAY!!!  Loretta

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2010 08:10PM precioustime wrote: cwrightrn:  Don't know if this makes any difference or not-- BUT I received radiation treatment to mediastinal lymph node in middle of my chest which has been 5 weeks since I completed.  I developed a cough about 2 weeks into my radiation treatment and was told that this is possible due to the area that were giving radiation.  I have also read something about possibly getting pneumonitis after completing radiation.  2 weeks ago I was put on 40mg tapering dose of Prednisone and noticed much of an improvement -- I see that Prednisone unfortunately has not worked for you.  In all that-- I do believe that radiation can cause this type of cough and inflammation that you are experiencing.  Sending positive thoughts your way. Loretta
Posts.Title: Lymphangitic lung spread cwrightrn joju

Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2010 02:07AM precioustime wrote: joycey- I had BMX with rt. axilla dissection on 12/14/09 in which I had a slight ROM issue on the rt. arm but started to stretch and do upper extremity exercises that PT gave me to do-- ROM was improving-- Now I am currently doing RAD treatment and will be done 3/17/10.  I am noticing more ROM issues-- I believe it all has to do with Scar Tissue build up along with having rt. axilla dissection!  I am heading back to PT in a couple of weeks to see if we can break up some more scar tissue and continue with exercises.  I have already been fitted for a Lymphdema sleeve that I wear if I am doing any type of lifting or strenous activity.  I'm guessing it depends on the type of treatment you have done-- in which ROM can be an issue.  I also have hope that we can overcome ROM issue with help from PT.  Have you tried consulting with a PT?  Loretta
Posts.Title: range of motion in arm joycey57 painterly

Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2009 06:52AM precioustime wrote: Awesome that you are 4 years NED LindaLou!  These stories give so many women hope that there is life beyond diagnosis and treatment!  I am starting to count down the days before surgery December 14th.  I sure hope that I will be up and around before Christmas-- I have a 3 year old and would really like to make his Christmas bright!  He was such an inspiration to me while I was going thru 18 weeks of Chemo and I really don't want him to go through anymore of Mommy being sick and too tired to play with him Question for those ladies who have had bilateral mastectomy with nodes removed on one side-- Do you think I will be able to take care of my 3 year old alone a week after surgery? Thanks again for all your prayers and words of encouragement
Posts.Title: Neoadjudvant Chemo no surgery needed precioustime mumito

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2009 05:26PM - edited Dec 16, 2009 05:26PM by precioustime It's me again.  The Surgeon called me today and I got some news I really didn't want to hear....  BUT am still so glad that I decided on bilateral mastectomy!  As I said before--- After Chemo was complete, they could not find any cancer on the PET scan!!!  However, the pathology report showed 12/18 positive lymph nodes!!!! And I still had (2) small tumors less than 1 cm in my rt. breast.  Left breast was clean.  You ladies were so right on with going ahead with surgery even if you have a clean PET scan!!!  Radiation is next after I heal from surgery and I guess Tamoxifen for 5 years after that?
Posts.Title: Neoadjudvant Chemo no surgery needed precioustime mumito

Posts.Content: Jul 7, 2010 10:33AM precioustime wrote: Hi Jenn3: Did you have your Mediastinal area radiated?  I did and about 2 months after radiation I developed a cough and same feeling of not being able to take a deep breath (without coughing).....  Last week I had a PET/CT scan follow up (3 months post Rads)....  The good news was "no evidence of tumor"--- the other news was that there was some mild lung change.  (I can't find my diagnosis sheet to get correct wording-- BUT basically inflammation in the lung area most likely caused by radiation).  About 1 month after RADS I contacted the Oncologist to tell her of my coughing and breathing issues and she put me on Steroids for 4 weeks which had worked wonders-- Unfortunately Steroids also have S/E's.  After I was off of Steroids for a few weeks, I really noticed that my coughing was  getting worse-- especially after a good laugh!  (I Love to Laugh).....  The Oncologist then put me on Albuterol Inhaler that seems to help a little. Since my PET/CT scan I have only been to the Breast Surgeon who said this is probably pneumonitis and should not get any worse BUT nothing you can do for it? My thought is "yes" there is something I can do for it--- PRAY!  I pray that your breathing gets better and soon! Loretta
Posts.Title: CAN'T CATCH MY BREATH?????? jenn3 precioustime

Posts.Content: Dec 19, 2009 02:55PM precioustime wrote: SherriG-- Thank you soooo much for letting me know your story:)  This has really eased some of my concerns about them finding 12/18 lymph nodes positive.   I am doing very well after my bilateral and find myself trying to do things around the house that I'm not suppose to be doing.  I was taken back a little last night when I looked at myself in the mirror again-- it looked like a war zone.  I pray it gets better:) Thanks Again SherriG

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2010 10:58AM precioustime wrote: karen- I remember those dreaded words--I was leaving the unemployment office, got in my car to drive away and the phone rang!  The Gyn told me right over the phone "Sorry I have bad news--you have breast cancer!"  Boy was I sent for a Loop----- what a way to break the news!! Loretta
Posts.Title: What Date to use for Survival Status? precioustime Snewl

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2010 06:47PM precioustime wrote: Pure- After being diagnosed with BC and having 5 biopsies--- There was an enlarged Internal Mammary Node that showed up on MRI.  I also had a biopsy of that node which also came out positive. I then had Neo Adjudvant Chemo prior to surgery to see how well tumors would respond to Chemo.  I was given 6 treatments of TAC every 3rd week.  After Chemo was completed the Internal Mammary had shrunk 1/4 of it's original size. I am now 4 weeks post RADS.   Because of the Internal Mammary Node - I was given radiation on the TOMO machine and because of having BMX a Bollus was placed for all 32 treatments. I was radiated on both rt. and left side of Internal Mammary Nodes and basically the whole rt. side of my chest from the neck down and underneath my rt. arm where I had an axillary dissection.    Not sure if you ladies remember me --that after Chemo -the PET scan showed "no signs of cancer" except for internal mammary node that had shrunk 1/4 of it's size.  THEN the pathology report showed 2 tumors in rt. breast-- and 12+ lymph nodes!!!  This sure doesn't make me feel good about future PET scans if you know what I mean....   I am currently on Prednisone from a cough that I developed during RADS -- guessing Radiation related, HOWEVER it could be from Chemo??  On the Tamoxifen train too-- woo hoo....  JUST HAPPY to have these treatments behind me and working on getting physically healthier than I've ever been in my Life:) I wish you the best PURE-- You definitely have been through A LOT and I hope that you have smooth sailing real soon:)   Loretta
Posts.Title: Help with Rads Pure karen1956

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2010 06:07PM precioustime wrote: I had NeoAdjudvant Chemo and as soon as Chemo was completed - I requested the Port be removed ASAP.  The Port was removed 4 weeks post Chemo during my BMX-- I remember waking up from surgery and thinking "The PORT is GONE"!!!!   Losing my breasts were of my second concern! LOL  That is how much I dreaded the PORT. Lisa-- I also thought the Port was very uncomfortable- could not wear a bra the whole time.  Every day it felt uncomfortable--like it wasn't suppose to be there...  and in fact the Port was getting closer to the surface of the skin as time went by and I was even told that the reason was that the body believes it is a foreign substance and is trying to get rid of it.  Hang in there!  The Port placement will soon be just a Memory
Posts.Title: Power Port is Powerfully Painful! LRAllenM12 elenalb

Posts.Content: Jul 7, 2010 10:48AM precioustime wrote: iacai: I also had Neo Adjudvant Chemo which showed the tumors gone on PET/CT scan.  Pathology Report showed 2 small tumors left with 12 lymph nodes positive!!  I had thoughts of not having surgery --- BUT so GLAD I did!!!  After BMX-- I was also told I needed RADS !   I completed RADS 3/10 and now have a peace knowing that I did all treatments!!  Even though it's not easy going through everything we do-- we must keep fighting and putting one foot in front of the other until we hear the words "Cancer Free"!! Hang on and keep on keeping on! Loretta
Posts.Title: Did anyone choose not to have surgery and radiation? iacai gutsy

Posts.Content: Dec 13, 2009 04:33PM precioustime wrote: I did Neo- Adjudvant Chemo due to lymph node positive in my chest-- I also had 3 tumors in rt. breast, the largest was 2cm.  After Chemo completed 10/30/09 they could not find any cancer in breast or lymph nodes under my arm per PET scan-- only lymph node still positive in my chest that had shrank 1/4 of the size it was before chemo.  Tomorrow I will go into surgery to have Bilateral Mastectomy and will know for sure what the Chemo actually did per pathology report.  Hang in there and take one day at a time-- one treatment at a time:)  If it were not for God- I would not be!

Posts.Content: May 10, 2010 12:18PM precioustime wrote: I have not had a period since the first infusion of Chemo which has been 9 months ago.  I had FSH test a month ago which turned out high and in the menopausal state- HOWEVER when I visited the Gynecologist last week and she reviewed the blood work-- she said that it didn't matter how high FSH level is because Chemo brings your FSH level up.  She said that she had patients who didn't have a period for a year or two after Chemo and then Wham-- it came back!!

I really like these discussion boards-- being able to communicate with ladies who are going through or have gone through what you are! THANKS
